docs.lead_paragraph: Every evening, President Clinton, the baby boomer who came to office vowing not to be consumed by problems beyond America's shores, receives a brief personal note from Warren Christopher, his cautious, 71-year-old Secretary of State and veteran of four Democratic administrations. At first the notes were tutorial, guiding a President who had accused George Bush of paying too much attention to foreign affairs. Candidate Clinton had argued that human rights in China were more important than trade, that the fratricide in Bosnia was Europe's problem, that the United States could not and should not play the role of world policeman.

headline.main: On World Stage, Many Lessons for Clinton
